channel.title: Comments on: SQL Server Case/When Data Type problems
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Brian
item.dc:creator: Brian
item.description:
Great post. Try running the following query 10 times to convince yourself that SQL Server really does prefer numbers to strings:
SELECT CASE WHEN RAND() < 0.5 THEN 188 ELSE 'Foo' END AS WHATEVER;
item.content:encoded:
Great post. Try running the following query 10 times to convince yourself that SQL Server really does prefer numbers to strings:

SELECT CASE WHEN RAND() < 0.5 THEN 188 ELSE 'Foo' END AS WHATEVER;

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.description: Because SQL is trying to determine the return type of the case/when expression. The function does not exist so SQL cannot determine it's output type and therefore cannot determine the return type of the case/when.
item.content:encoded: Because SQL is trying to determine the return type of the case/when expression. The function does not exist so SQL cannot determine it’s output type and therefore cannot determine the return type of the case/when.

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.content:encoded:
The interesting problem related to this blog post is discussed in this thread

MSDN thread

So, the condition checks if the function exists and even if it doesn’t exist, it still attempts to call it.

item.title: By: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.description: Anonymous comments are never taken seriously.

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.content:encoded:
blogs serve several different purposes. The main two are to write articles on what you think is benefiting to the community as a new or old concept they should know and also to write about things you simply have just learned and want to pass along.

If you read anything on gmmastros’s history and web presence I think you’d know you just made yourself look like the one needing 101 educational classes

item.title: By: SQL Smarty
item.dc:creator: SQL Smarty
item.description: I thought you learned this at the SQL 101 class...if you just found this out and are actually in a developer role, you need to request a "Beginner" training course from your manager.
item.content:encoded: I thought you learned this at the SQL 101 class…if you just found this out and are actually in a developer role, you need to request a “Beginner” training course from your manager.

item.title: By: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.dc:creator: George Mastros (gmmastros)
item.content:encoded:
Another trick could have been:

WHEN 0=1 Then ‘1’

I chose to put the convert code in there because real world code may not be using hard coded literals, but may actually have a column there instead. I wanted to emphasize that a conversion to a string was important to ensure a consistent data type for the return value.
